questions.text: A 66-year-old man in the ICU with septic shock is on mechanical ventilation for 3 days and receiving vasopressors for hemodynamic support. He has no history of gastrointestinal bleeding. Current labs show platelets 48,000/μL, INR 1.7, and creatinine 2.1 mg/dL. He is being fed via a nasogastric tube but is unable to tolerate oral medications. A junior resident suggests continuing only fluids and lactulose due to infection concerns with acid-suppressive agents. What is the most appropriate approach for stress ulcer prophylaxis?

options.label: C
options.text: Administer H₂ blocker in all ventilated ICU patients

options.label: D
options.text: Avoid prophylaxis unless GI bleed occurs

questions.correct_answer: A. Administer PPI or H₂ blocker
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Administer PPI or H₂ blocker

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In critically ill ICU patients with bleeding diathesis or mechanical ventilation >48 hours, stress ulcer prophylaxis with PPI (preferred) or H₂ blocker is recommended. The benefits of prophylaxis outweigh infection risks in high-risk patients.

questions.text: A 6-month-old male infant is brought to the paediatrician for a routine examination. On physical examination, the right side of the scrotum is empty, and the testis is palpated in the inguinal canal. The parents are concerned and ask about possible complications their child may face in the future if this condition is left untreated. Which of the following is the least likely complication associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vaginal hydrocele

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Undescended testis (cryptorchidism) is associated with several complications if not surgically corrected early, including infertility, malignancy risk (seminoma), inguinal hernia, congenital hydrocele, and testicular torsion . However, a vaginal hydrocele is less likely in this condition since it typically involves the scrotal testis .
  • ➤ Undescended testis (cryptorchidism) is associated with several complications if not surgically corrected early, including infertility, malignancy risk (seminoma), inguinal hernia, congenital hydrocele, and testicular torsion .
  • ➤ Undescended testis (cryptorchidism)
  • ➤ infertility, malignancy risk (seminoma), inguinal hernia, congenital hydrocele, and testicular torsion
  • ➤ However, a vaginal hydrocele is less likely in this condition since it typically involves the scrotal testis .
  • ➤ vaginal hydrocele
  • ➤ less likely
  • ➤ scrotal testis

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with acute onset of profuse watery diarrhea described as resembling “rice water” or rice gruel. He recently returned from a coastal region in South Asia. He appears dehydrated, and stool cultures are pending. The physician suspects a bacterial toxin that increases intestinal permeability. Which of the following cellular structures is most likely impaired, leading to the patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Zona occludens

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Damage to tight junctions (zona occludens) increases paracellular permeability in the gut, leading to leakage of fluids and electrolytes, a mechanism often exploited by pathogens causing secretory diarrhea.
  • ➤ tight junctions (zona occludens)

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with secondary infertility visits the clinic with complaints of irregular menstrual cycles and inability to conceive for 2 years. After ruling out anatomical and endocrinological causes, you decide to start ovulation induction with Clomiphene citrate 50 mg/day for 5 days. On which days of her menstrual cycle should she begin the medication for optimal follicular recruitment and ovulation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Day 2 to Day 6

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clomiphene citrate is started from Day 2 to Day 6 of the menstrual cycle for ovulation induction in anovulatory infertility. It acts by increasing FSH secretion and promoting follicular maturation.
  • ➤ Day 2 to Day 6

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents with multiple pruritic, erythematous papules distributed over his forehead, neck, and the V-area of his chest. He reports that the rash has recurred every summer for the past four years and tends to resolve spontaneously during the winter. He denies any systemic symptoms. He works outdoors and frequently uses various sunscreen and cosmetic products. Examination reveals discrete lichenified papules with mild scaling in the affected areas. What is the most appropriate diagnostic test to identify the underlying cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Patch test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patch testing is the investigation of choice for diagnosing allergic contact dermatitis caused by delayed-type hypersensitivity. It is particularly useful in chronic, relapsing, photo-distributed rashes exacerbated by topical exposures.
  • ➤ allergic contact dermatitis

questions.text: A child presents with anemia, seizures, intellectual disability, and hair texture as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Menkes disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Menkes disease is a copper transport disorder marked by kinky hair (pili torti) , neurodevelopmental delay, seizures, and failure to thrive. It is confirmed by low serum copper and ceruloplasmin levels and characteristic hair microscopy findings.
  • ➤ Menkes disease
  • ➤ kinky hair (pili torti)

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the nutritional composition of human milk is/are correct? Human milk contains higher concentrations of whey and lactalbumin compared to casein. The calcium to phosphorus ratio in human milk is less than 1. Human milk is richer in polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) and has lower protein content than cow’s milk. The osmolality of human milk is approximately 290 mOsm/L. Iron content in human milk ranges between 1.5–2.0 mg/100 mL.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 3, and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Human milk provides optimal nutrition tailored to infants, with a high whey-to-casein ratio, low protein content, essential fatty acids, ideal osmolality, and enhanced mineral bioavailability despite low absolute concentrations.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man with a history of neurosyphilis presents with difficulty in vision, especially in dim light. On examination, his pupils are small, irregular, and do not constrict in response to light, but do constrict during accommodation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Argyll Robertson pupil

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Argyll Robertson pupils are classically seen in neurosyphilis and are characterized by small, irregular pupils that accommodate but do not react to light — a key example of light-near dissociation.

questions.text: An 11-year-old child presents with failure to thrive and laboratory findings reveal metabolic acidosis with an elevated anion gap. Which of the following conditions is not typically associated with high anion gap metabolic acidosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Renal tubular acidosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Renal tubular acidosis presents with normal anion gap metabolic acidosis , unlike conditions such as Methanol exposure, Uremia, DKA, Propylene glycol exposure, Infection/Isoniazid, Lactic acidosis, Ethylene glycol exposure, Salicylates ( Mnemonic - MUDPILES ) which present with a high anion gap .
  • ➤ Renal tubular acidosis
  • ➤ normal anion gap metabolic acidosis
  • ➤ Mnemonic - MUDPILES
  • ➤ high anion gap

questions.text: Which of the following amoebae is least likely to be associated with neuropathogenesis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dientamoeba fragilis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dientamoeba fragilis is a gastrointestinal parasite and is not associated with CNS disease, unlike other free-living amoebae such as Naegleria, Acanthamoeba, and Balamuthia which are neuropathogenic.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the clinic during flu season with high-grade fever, dry cough, myalgia, and nasal congestion. The symptoms began abruptly two days ago. A rapid antigen test confirms infection with a virus that has a negative-sense RNA genome and neuraminidase activity as part of its envelope glycoproteins. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Influenza virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Influenza virus is a negative-sense RNA virus that uniquely expresses both hemagglutinin and neuraminidase on its surface—key for viral entry and release—distinguishing it from other respiratory viruses.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man who recently returned from a conflict zone presents with fever and generalized rash. On examination, he is febrile and found to have body lice in his clothing. The rash is widespread but notably spares the palms and soles. Which of the following is the most likely etiologic agent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rickettsia prowazekii

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rickettsia prowazekii causes epidemic typhus, transmitted by body lice, and presents with fever and a rash that spares the palms and soles—commonly seen in overcrowded or military settings.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding hematological changes in normal pregnancy are true? Pregnancy is considered a hypercoagulable state. Plasma fibrinogen levels decrease due to increased consumption. Platelet count may slightly decrease due to hemodilution and increased consumption, typically without adverse pregnancy outcomes. There is an increase in plasma levels of clotting factors I, II, VII, VIII, IX, and X. Clotting time is significantly prolonged in the third trimester.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1, 3, and 4 only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pregnancy induces a hypercoagulable state , marked by increased fibrinogen and several clotting factors, with mild thrombocytopenia in late pregnancy due to hemodilution and platelet consumption. Clotting time remains unchanged.
  • ➤ hypercoagulable state

questions.text: Match the following types of delusions with their definitions:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1-D, 2-B, 3-A, 4-C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Delusion of persecution : The belief that one is being harmed, harassed, or conspired against — classic in paranoid schizophrenia . Delusion of grandeur : The belief that one possesses extraordinary powers, wealth, or fame — commonly seen in mania . Delusion of reference : Believing that neutral events (like TV shows or newspaper articles) have a special and personal meaning — often observed in schizophrenia . Nihilistic delusion : The false belief that oneself, others, or the world does not exist — seen in severe depressive states or Cotard syndrome .
  • ➤ Delusion of persecution : The belief that one is being harmed, harassed, or conspired against — classic in paranoid schizophrenia .
  • ➤ Delusion of persecution
  • ➤ classic in paranoid schizophrenia
  • ➤ Delusion of grandeur : The belief that one possesses extraordinary powers, wealth, or fame — commonly seen in mania .
  • ➤ Delusion of grandeur
  • ➤ mania
  • ➤ Delusion of reference : Believing that neutral events (like TV shows or newspaper articles) have a special and personal meaning — often observed in schizophrenia .
  • ➤ Delusion of reference
  • ➤ schizophrenia
  • ➤ Nihilistic delusion : The false belief that oneself, others, or the world does not exist — seen in severe depressive states or Cotard syndrome .
  • ➤ Nihilistic delusion
  • ➤ severe depressive states or Cotard syndrome

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman from a rural community is interested in becoming an ASHA worker. She has completed formal education up to 8th grade and is fluent in the local language. However, she does not meet the standard eligibility criteria. Under which of the following conditions can she still be selected as an ASHA worker?

options.label: A
options.text: If she belongs to a tribal area where education criteria are relaxed

options.label: B
options.text: If she completes a special government-sponsored bridge training course

options.label: C
options.text: If she has previous experience working as an Anganwadi worker

options.label: D
options.text: If she is nominated by the Panchayat based on community support

questions.correct_answer: A. If she belongs to a tribal area where education criteria are relaxed
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) If she belongs to a tribal area where education criteria are relaxed

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ASHA worker selection requires a minimum 10th-grade education, but this is relaxed for tribal areas where literacy levels are lower.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with longstanding seropositive rheumatoid arthritis presents with progressive dyspnea and mild pleuritic chest pain. He denies fever or cough. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral pleural effusions. Thoracentesis yields a cloudy, milky-appearing fluid. Pleural fluid analysis shows protein 4.5 g/dL, cholesterol 280 mg/dL, triglycerides 35 mg/dL, and presence of cholesterol crystals. Gram stain and culture are negative, and there is no neutrophilic predominance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pseudochylothorax

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pseudochylothorax is a chronic cholesterol-rich exudative pleural effusion, typically seen in rheumatoid arthritis or tuberculosis, characterized by high cholesterol, low triglycerides, and cholesterol crystals in pleural fluid.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of ezetimibe in the treatment of hypercholesterolemia?

options.label: B
options.text: Inhibition of cholesterol absorption in the small intestine

options.label: C
options.text: Inhibition of microsomal triglyceride transfer protein

options.label: D
options.text: Activation of peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPAR-α)

questions.correct_answer: B. Inhibition of cholesterol absorption in the small intestine
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Inhibition of cholesterol absorption in the small intestine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ezetimibe lowers LDL cholesterol by inhibiting cholesterol absorption in the small intestine via NPC1L1 transporters. It is often used in combination with statins for enhanced lipid-lowering efficacy.
  • ➤ Ezetimibe lowers LDL cholesterol by inhibiting cholesterol absorption in the small intestine via NPC1L1 transporters. It is often used in combination with statins for enhanced lipid-lowering efficacy.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant lady on leprosy treatment has type 2 Lepra reaction. Next line of management is?

options.label: A
options.text: Stop leprosy drugs and add steroids

options.label: D
options.text: Continue anti-leprosy drugs and add steroids

questions.correct_answer: D. Continue anti-leprosy drugs and add steroids
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Continue anti-leprosy drugs and add steroids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a pregnant woman with Type 2 Lepra reaction , the correct approach is to continue anti-leprosy treatment and add corticosteroids . Thalidomide is contraindicated in pregnancy , and anti-leprosy therapy should never be stopped during a lepra reaction.
  • ➤ pregnant woman with Type 2 Lepra reaction
  • ➤ continue anti-leprosy treatment and add corticosteroids
  • ➤ Thalidomide is contraindicated in pregnancy
  • ➤ Treatment of Type 1 Lepra reaction: Prednisolone Treatment for type 2 lepra reaction: For Mild cases – Antipyretic analgesics (Aspirin) For Severe cases – Prednisolone For steroid withdrawal symptoms - Clofazimine
  • ➤ Treatment of Type 1 Lepra reaction: Prednisolone
  • ➤ Treatment of Type 1 Lepra reaction: Prednisolone
  • ➤ Treatment for type 2 lepra reaction: For Mild cases – Antipyretic analgesics (Aspirin) For Severe cases – Prednisolone For steroid withdrawal symptoms - Clofazimine
  • ➤ Treatment for type 2 lepra reaction:
  • ➤ For Mild cases – Antipyretic analgesics (Aspirin) For Severe cases – Prednisolone For steroid withdrawal symptoms - Clofazimine
  • ➤ For Mild cases – Antipyretic analgesics (Aspirin)
  • ➤ For Mild cases – Antipyretic analgesics (Aspirin)
  • ➤ For Severe cases – Prednisolone
  • ➤ For Severe cases – Prednisolone
  • ➤ For steroid withdrawal symptoms - Clofazimine
  • ➤ For steroid withdrawal symptoms - Clofazimine

questions.text: A 74-year-old man from Coimbatore is admitted for community-acquired pneumonia and has been receiving intravenous ceftriaxone for 6 days. He now develops watery, foul-smelling diarrhea associated with mild cramping and generalized fatigue. Vitals: T 99.8°F, HR 94/min, BP 116/72 mmHg. He is not hypotensive and has no abdominal distension. Labs reveal WBC 13,800/mm³ and creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (baseline 1.0). Colonoscopy shows the following lesions. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oral vancomycin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In nonfulminant Clostridioides difficile infection, oral vancomycin is the current first-line treatment over metronidazole, especially in elderly or hospitalized patients. Route and severity stratification guide therapy; IV vancomycin has no role in treating CDI.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male with treatment-resistant focal seizures is prescribed a newer-generation antiepileptic drug. The chosen medication exerts its anticonvulsant effect by antagonizing AMPA receptors. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)  Perampanel

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Perampanel is an antiepileptic drug that acts by antagonizing AMPA receptors, thereby reducing excitatory glutamatergic transmission in seizure disorders.
  • ➤ Perampanel is an antiepileptic drug that acts by antagonizing AMPA receptors, thereby reducing excitatory glutamatergic transmission in seizure disorders.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with complaints of fatigue and early satiety. Physical examination reveals splenomegaly. Laboratory findings show pancytopenia. A bone marrow biopsy is performed, and electron microscopy of one of the abnormal cells is shown in the image. Which of the following best identifies the cell shown?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hairy cell

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hairy cell leukemia is a B-cell neoplasm characterized by cytoplasmic projections visible on electron microscopy. It presents with splenomegaly, pancytopenia, and a “dry tap” on bone marrow aspiration due to marrow fibrosis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida woman at 34 weeks gestation with preeclampsia with severe features is receiving intravenous magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis. After 8 hours of infusion, the nurse reports that the patient appears drowsy, has a respiratory rate of 10/min, and no elicitable patellar reflexes. Her urine output is 20 mL/hour. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Increase the magnesium sulfate infusion rate

options.label: D
options.text: Intubate and start mechanical ventilation immediately

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Administer intravenous calcium gluconate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Loss of deep tendon reflexes is the earliest clinical sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity. Calcium gluconate is the antidote and should be administered immediately in symptomatic cases, along with stopping MgSO₄ infusion.
  • ➤ Loss of deep tendon reflexes
  • ➤ Calcium gluconate

questions.text: Match the Following: Muscles of Mastication and Their Actions: Column A (Muscles) Temporalis Masseter Lateral pterygoid Medial pterygoid Column B (Action on Mandible) Elevation and Retraction (posterior fibers) Depression and Unilateral Jaw Swinging Elevation and Protrusion (superficial fibers) Elevation and Protrusion
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ All muscles of mastication are supplied by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3) . Their coordinated actions help in complex jaw movements like chewing, biting, and grinding.
  • ➤ All muscles of mastication are supplied by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3) .
  • ➤ mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3)
  • ➤ Their coordinated actions help in complex jaw movements like chewing, biting, and grinding.

questions.text: Match the following: Column A (Oxygen Delivery Devices) Nasal Cannula Simple Face Mask Venturi Mask Non-Rebreather Mask High-Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC) Column B (Maximum FiO₂ Delivered) Up to 40% Up to 50-60% Up to 80% Up to 100% Up to 60%
questions.explanation: Ans. B) 1-A, 2-B, 3-E, 4-C, 5-D

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with a 1-month history of chronic cough, progressive shortness of breath, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral upper lobe infiltrates with cavitary lesions. Sputum culture grown on Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium yields colonies that test positive for MPT64 antigen. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mycobacterium tuberculosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Detection of MPT64 antigen confirms infection with the Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex. Among its members, Mycobacterium tuberculosis is the most common cause of pulmonary TB, particularly in immunocompetent patients with typical cavitary lung lesions.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female with a history of chronic liver disease presents to the emergency department with massive hematemesis and signs of hypovolemic shock, including hypotension and tachycardia. Immediate stabilization with IV fluids, Terlipressin, and blood transfusion is initiated. What is the next immediate step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Variceal banding

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with massive hematemesis due to esophageal varices, the next immediate step in management is endoscopic variceal banding to control active bleeding. Pharmacologic therapy with vasoactive agents (e.g., octreotide) should be started simultaneously. TIPSS and surgical options are reserved for refractory cases, while balloon tamponade is used only as a bridge in uncontrolled bleeding.
  • ➤ In a patient with massive hematemesis due to esophageal varices, the next immediate step in management is endoscopic variceal banding to control active bleeding.
  • ➤ next immediate step in management
  • ➤ endoscopic variceal banding
  • ➤ Pharmacologic therapy with vasoactive agents (e.g., octreotide) should be started simultaneously.
  • ➤ vasoactive agents
  • ➤ TIPSS and surgical options are reserved for refractory cases, while balloon tamponade is used only as a bridge in uncontrolled bleeding.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe generalized muscle spasms and opisthotonos (arching of the back), several days after sustaining a puncture wound to the foot while working outdoors. He had not received tetanus immunization in over 15 years. The person shows a classic hyperextended posture consistent with tetanic spasms. The toxin responsible for this condition acts through which of the following mechanisms?

options.label: A
options.text: Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release

options.label: D
options.text: Cleavage of SNARE proteins, preventing acetylcholine release

questions.correct_answer: A. Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tetanospasmin inhibits the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters (GABA and glycine) by cleaving SNARE proteins in interneurons, leading to unopposed muscle contraction and spastic paralysis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, currently 9 weeks pregnant, presents with a 4-day history of low-grade fever and a maculopapular rash that began on her face and has spread downward to her trunk and extremities. She also complains of mild arthralgias. She has no documented history of MMR vaccination or prior rubella infection. On examination, she is febrile (38.3°C), and there is postauricular lymphadenopathy. Laboratory tests confirm a positive rubella-specific IgM. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Review at 12 weeks for early anomaly scan

options.label: D
options.text: Detailed counseling about potential fetal risks and management options

questions.correct_answer: D. Detailed counseling about potential fetal risks and management options
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Detailed counseling about potential fetal risks and management options

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rubella infection in early pregnancy requires comprehensive counseling regarding the high risk of congenital rubella syndrome , rather than immediate treatment or termination. The management is centered on informed decision-making rather than interventions.
  • ➤ comprehensive counseling
  • ➤ congenital rubella syndrome

questions.text: A 28-year-old healthcare worker presents for follow-up after a documented needle-stick injury involving a patient later found to be positive for hepatitis B virus (HBV). His serological results are being monitored over time to assess for acute infection, resolution, or chronicity. Which of the following markers is expected to be detectable regardless of whether the patient completely recovers or progresses to chronic HBV infection?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Anti-HBc

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anti-HBc antibodies are present in all individuals with past or current HBV infection, regardless of recovery or progression to chronic hepatitis B.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding cardiovascular examination findings in pregnancy are correct? The apex beat is displaced to the 4th intercostal space and lies 2.5 cm medial to the midclavicular line. A physiological systolic murmur may be heard at the apical or pulmonary area due to increased blood volume. A mammary murmur can be heard in the 2nd and 3rd left intercostal spaces due to increased internal mammary blood flow. An S3 heart sound may be present due to rapid diastolic ventricular filling. ECG may show left axis deviation but is otherwise typically normal.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Statements 2, 3, 4, and 5 are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During pregnancy, cardiovascular adaptations include lateral displacement of the heart, increased cardiac output, and blood volume, often manifesting as benign auscultatory findings like systolic murmurs , mammary murmurs , and S3 . ECG changes such as left axis deviation may be observed but are generally benign.
  • ➤ systolic murmurs
  • ➤ mammary murmurs
  • ➤ S3
  • ➤ left axis deviation

questions.text: A 74-year-old man from Surat with a history of diabetes and atrial fibrillation presents with sudden severe diffuse abdominal pain, multiple episodes of vomiting, and mild generalized abdominal tenderness. BP is 110/70 mmHg, HR is 36/min, and SpO₂ is 97% on room air. Serum lactate is markedly elevated at 6.1 mmol/L. ECG is shown. On examination, his abdomen is soft without guarding or rebound tenderness. What is the next best step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) CT Angiography

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with atrial fibrillation and sudden severe abdominal pain disproportionate to examination findings, acute mesenteric ischemia must be suspected, and CT angiography is the essential first diagnostic step to confirm vascular occlusion and guide management.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe respiratory distress, audible wheezing, and use of accessory muscles. She is unable to speak in full sentences. Vital signs show tachypnea, tachycardia, and an oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. She is diagnosed with status asthmaticus. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for initial administration via nebulization?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Formoterol plus budesonide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Formoterol (a fast-acting LABA) combined with budesonide (an inhaled corticosteroid) can be nebulized for rapid relief in status asthmaticus, offering both bronchodilation and anti-inflammatory effects.
  • ➤ Formoterol (a fast-acting LABA) combined with budesonide (an inhaled corticosteroid) can be nebulized for rapid relief in status asthmaticus, offering both bronchodilation and anti-inflammatory effects.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman undergoes renal function testing as part of a clinical research study. Her urine sample shows a high concentration of a test substance, and the goal is to determine the rate at which her kidneys clear this substance from plasma. Which of the following is the correct formula for calculating the renal clearance rate (Cₛ) of a substance? Us​ = Urine concentration of the substance V = Urine flow rate Ps​ = Plasma concentration of the substance
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The renal clearance of a substance is calculated using the formula
  • ➤ reflecting the efficiency of renal elimination and forming the basis of key renal function tests.

questions.text: A 29-year-old pregnant woman with a history of mechanical mitral valve replacement is being managed with anticoagulation therapy. She is currently 35 weeks pregnant and has been on warfarin since the end of the first trimester. She presents for a routine prenatal follow-up. Her INR is within the therapeutic range, and she has no signs of bleeding or thromboembolism. What is the most appropriate next step in her anticoagulation management?

options.label: A
options.text: Continue warfarin until the onset of labor

options.label: B
options.text: Switch to unfractionated heparin at 36 weeks gestation

options.label: D
options.text: Administer low-dose aspirin instead of warfarin

questions.correct_answer: B. Switch to unfractionated heparin at 36 weeks gestation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Switch to unfractionated heparin at 36 weeks gestation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In pregnant women requiring long-term anticoagulation (e.g., for mechanical heart valves), warfarin should be stopped at 36 weeks gestation and replaced by heparin to allow safer peripartum management and minimize bleeding complications during delivery.
  • ➤ warfarin should be stopped at 36 weeks gestation
  • ➤ heparin

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with resting tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability. A coronal section of the brain is shown. Which of the following regions, when affected, is responsible for the observed neurotransmitter deficiency in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Degeneration of the Substantia Nigra results in a dopamine deficit, which is the primary cause of the motor symptoms seen in Parkinson's disease.
  • ➤ Degeneration of the Substantia Nigra results in a dopamine deficit, which is the primary cause of the motor symptoms seen in Parkinson's disease.
  • ➤ Substantia Nigra

questions.text: Assertion (A): During head and neck surgeries, accidental injury to the internal jugular vein can result in venous air embolism, leading to a sudden drop in end-tidal CO₂ (etCO₂), hypotension, and cardiac arrhythmias. questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding supine vena cava syndrome are correct? The condition is caused by compression of the inferior vena cava by the gravid uterus, especially in the supine position. Collateral venous circulation via the azygous and paravertebral veins usually compensates for vena cava compression. Symptoms may include hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope when collateral circulation fails. Supine vena cava syndrome is managed by placing the patient in a Trendelenburg position.

Management includes placing the patient in the lateral decubitus position to relieve compression.

  • ➤ supine position
  • ➤ hypotension and syncope
  • ➤ lateral decubitus position

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding typical HRCT findings in fungal pneumonia are correct? questions.text: The genetic code is degenerate, meaning that most amino acids are encoded by more than one codon. This degeneracy often allows silent mutations (point mutations that do not change the amino acid) to occur without affecting the protein function. However some amino acids are coded by a single unique codon, and any mutation in that codon is more likely to result in a change in protein synthesis. Which of the following amino acids is coded by only one codon and thus does not exhibit degeneracy in the genetic code?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Methionine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methionine is coded exclusively by a single codon (AUG), which also serves as the universal start codon in protein synthesis. Unlike most amino acids that have multiple codons (degeneracy), methionine’s lack of codon redundancy means mutations affecting AUG are more likely to disrupt protein initiation or alter protein function.
  • ➤ Methionine is coded exclusively by a single codon (AUG), which also serves as the universal start codon in protein synthesis.
  • ➤ Unlike most amino acids that have multiple codons (degeneracy), methionine’s lack of codon redundancy means mutations affecting AUG are more likely to disrupt protein initiation or alter protein function.

He is afebrile, and there are no signs of active bleeding. A peripheral smear shows thrombocytopenia without schistocytes. What is true regarding the likely diagnosis?

options.label: A

options.label: C
options.text: Risk is higher in medical vs surgical patients and occurs more in males

He had normal length and weight at birth Catch-up growth typically occurs at 6–12 months of age His bone age is greater than chronological age His height velocity assumes a normal rate during middle childhood Final adult height is typically normal
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A, E

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In constitutional growth delay, children have normal birth parameters, delayed bone age, and delayed puberty, but they ultimately reach normal adult height. The key distinguishing feature is the bone age lag behind chronological age with no pathological findings.
  • ➤ In constitutional growth delay, children have normal birth parameters, delayed bone age, and delayed puberty, but they ultimately reach normal adult height.
  • ➤ The key distinguishing feature is the bone age lag behind chronological age with no pathological findings.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding early pregnancy signs is/are correct? Chadwick’s sign is characterized by a bluish discoloration of the anterior vaginal wall observed around the 8th week of pregnancy. Osiander’s sign involves increased pulsation felt through the lateral fornices and typically appears before the 4th week. Goodell’s sign refers to cervical softening and is evident as early as the 6th week of gestation. Palmer’s sign involves rhythmic uterine contractions and is elicited on bimanual examination between the 4th and 8th weeks.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Only 1, 3, and 4 are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Several clinical signs aid in the early diagnosis of pregnancy. These signs are classified based on their anatomical location (vaginal, cervical, uterine) and the time at which they typically appear. Recognizing these signs can support clinical diagnosis before imaging confirmation.

questions.text: Which of the following environmental factors is most likely to contribute to increased Xenopsylla cheopis-mediated Yersinia pestis outbreaks?

questions.text: Autopsy of a bombing victim reveals: Intestinal perforation Skull base fracture with underlying brain contusions Absence of external lacerations Carboxyhemoglobin level of 38% What is the least likely blast injury type present?

Ans. A) Secondary

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman is recovering from a recently treated ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). She received appropriate acute therapy and is now discharged on dual antiplatelet therapy, atorvastatin, and a beta-blocker. Which of the following beta-blockers should be avoided in this patient due to its partial agonist activity?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pindolol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Beta-blockers with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity, such as pindolol, celiprolol, alprenolol, acebutolol should be avoided in patients recovering from myocardial infarction due to their partial agonist effect, which may blunt the cardioprotective benefits of beta-blockade.
  • ➤ Beta-blockers with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity, such as pindolol, celiprolol, alprenolol, acebutolol should be avoided in patients recovering from myocardial infarction due to their partial agonist effect, which may blunt the cardioprotective benefits of beta-blockade.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents with a slowly enlarging, painless thyroid nodule. She denies any symptoms of thyrotoxicosis or hypothyroidism. Fine-needle aspiration reveals cells with neuroendocrine features, and the biopsy specimen shows amyloid deposition in the stroma, as highlighted in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely type of amyloid protein associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) ACal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In medullary thyroid carcinoma, amyloid deposits are composed of ACal, which is derived from calcitonin secreted by neoplastic C cells.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with progressive shortness of breath over the past 4 months. Imaging reveals a cavitatory lesion in the right lower lobe of the lung. She undergoes a lobectomy, and the histopathological section from the lesion is shown. Based on this, what is the most likely diagnosis and characteristic cyst wall structure?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Echinococcal cyst; 3-layered cyst

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Echinococcus granulosus causes hydatid cysts characterized histologically by three layers: an inner germinal layer, a laminated membrane, and an outer fibrous capsule. This appearance is pathognomonic and helps differentiate it from other parasitic infections.
  • ➤ Echinococcus granulosus causes hydatid cysts characterized histologically by three layers: an inner germinal layer, a laminated membrane, and an outer fibrous capsule.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with Child C Cirrhosis and Hepatitis C is undergoing a liver transplant. Which anatomical structure should the surgeon prepare to anastomose first in the recipient?
questions.explanation:

The order of anastomosis in the recipient of a liver transplant is:

questions.text: An 80-year-old man from Pune with a history of cervical spondylosis is brought to the emergency department after falling backwards in his bathroom. Since the fall, he reports clumsiness in his hands and difficulty feeding himself and buttoning his shirt. On examination, there is marked weakness of grip and reduced strength in shoulder abduction and elbow flexion. Lower limb strength is relatively preserved, and no sensory level is identified. Deep tendon reflexes are brisk in all four limbs, and there is no bladder involvement at this time. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Central cord syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Central cord syndrome typically presents in elderly patients after cervical hyperextension injury, leading to disproportionately greater upper limb weakness due to central corticospinal tract involvement. Lower limbs are relatively spared, and MRI often reveals cervical cord edema.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man hospitalized for sepsis develops sudden thrombocytopenia after several days of unfractionated heparin therapy. His platelet count drops by more than 50%, and he is diagnosed with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). The treating team discontinues heparin and initiates an alternative anticoagulant that directly inhibits thrombin without requiring antithrombin III and is not neutralized by platelet factor. Which of the following is the most appropriate anticoagulant in this setting?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lepirudin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lepirudin is a direct thrombin inhibitor used as an alternative anticoagulant in heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. It acts independently of antithrombin III and is not affected by platelet factor 4. Direct thrombin inhibitor like Lepirudin, Argatroban are injectable and Dabigatran is oral.
  • ➤ Lepirudin is a direct thrombin inhibitor used as an alternative anticoagulant in heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. It acts independently of antithrombin III and is not affected by platelet factor 4.
  • ➤ Direct thrombin inhibitor like Lepirudin, Argatroban are injectable and Dabigatran is oral.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male presents with progressive shortness of breath and fatigue for the past 6 months. He denies cough, wheezing, or orthopnea. On examination, breath sounds are diminished bilaterally, and there is paradoxical abdominal movement during inspiration. Pulmonary function tests reveal: FEV1: Decreased FEV1/FVC: Normal TLC: Decreased DLCO: Normal Maximal Inspiratory Pressure (Pimax): Markedly Decreased Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on this pulmonary function profile?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Respiratory muscle weakness

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A restrictive PFT pattern with normal DLCO and significantly decreased inspiratory pressure (Pimax) is highly suggestive of respiratory muscle weakness , distinguishing it from interstitial lung diseases or chest wall abnormalities.
  • ➤ respiratory muscle weakness

questions.text: Which of the following statements about pleomorphic adenoma is incorrect? The tumor commonly shows the presence of myoepithelial cells, contributing to its biphasic nature. Areas of chondroid (cartilage-like) differentiation are frequently observed on microscopy. Keratin pearls are a classic histological hallmark of pleomorphic adenoma. Although benign, pleomorphic adenomas can sometimes show perineural invasion or recur if incompletely excised.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Only statement 3 is incorrect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pleomorphic adenoma is a benign salivary gland tumor characterized by both epithelial and myoepithelial cells, often displaying chondroid or myxoid stroma. It does not show keratin pearls, which are specific to squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 36-year-old HIV-positive man with a CD4 count of 170 cells/mm³ presents for routine follow-up. He is asymptomatic and currently not on any prophylactic medications. The physician initiates therapy with a combination drug that inhibits sequential steps in folate metabolism. Which of the following infections is this medication most likely prescribed to prevent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cotrimoxazole (Trimethoprim–Sulfamethoxazole) is the drug of choice for prophylaxis and treatment of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia in HIV patients with CD4 <200 cells/mm³. It inhibits folate synthesis at two distinct steps.
  • ➤ Cotrimoxazole (Trimethoprim–Sulfamethoxazole) is the drug of choice for prophylaxis and treatment of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia in HIV patients with CD4 <200 cells/mm³. It inhibits folate synthesis at two distinct steps.

questions.text: You are evaluating the developmental progress of an infant during a routine well-child visit. You are shown a set of images that represent different developmental milestones achieved at different ages. Arrange the milestones in the correct order based on their typical age of appearance, starting from the earliest to the latest.

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman from Nagpur with atrial fibrillation on chronic warfarin therapy presents for routine anticoagulation monitoring. She reports feeling well, with no history of recent trauma, bleeding gums, hematuria, or melena. She has a known past history of peptic ulcer disease but no active gastrointestinal symptoms currently. She is hemodynamically stable. Her rest of the laboratory results are as follow:

options.label: A
options.text: Instruct the patient to skip the next 3 doses of warfarin and discharge home

options.label: B
options.text: Hold warfarin and administer fresh frozen plasma

options.label: C

options.label: D

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient came to the OPD after a fall on his hand. He is now experiencing pain in the hand region. The X-ray of the patient is given below. Identify the type of joint marked in the X-ray?
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with his first generalized tonic-clonic seizure. He recently immigrated from rural Honduras. He has no history of trauma, alcohol use, or chronic medical illness. On examination, he is postictal but arousable. A non-contrast CT scan of the head is shown below.   • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Assertion (A): Antigenic drift results in a gradual, sequential change in the antigenic structure of the influenza virus. Reason (R): The new antigens formed by antigenic drift are completely unrelated to the previous viral antigens.

options.label: C

questions.text: Which of the following interventions would be most effective in mitigating the economic impact of a rising Old Age Dependency Ratio (OADR) in a rapidly aging country?

options.label: A
options.text: Shifting from a defined-benefit pension system to a defined-contribution pension system

options.label: B
options.text: Reducing healthcare access for the elderly to lower medical costs

options.label: C
options.text: Implementing tax cuts to encourage higher birth rates

options.label: D
options.text: Increasing investment in AI and automation to replace elderly workers

questions.correct_answer: A. Shifting from a defined-benefit pension system to a defined-contribution pension system
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Shifting from a defined-benefit pension system to a defined-contribution pension system

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Shifting from a defined-benefit to a defined-contribution pension system is an effective strategy to reduce financial strain from a rising Old Age DR.

questions.text: A 31-year-old postpartum woman from Delhi presents to the emergency department with acute-onset confusion and bleeding gums, occurring 7 days after receiving multiple blood transfusions during labor. She is febrile, and her GCS is 12/15. Examination reveals lesions as shown in the image below. Initial labs show hemoglobin 9.8 g/dL and a platelet count of 4,000/μL. CT brain reveals an intracerebral hemorrhage without mass effect. Despite transfusion of 10 units of platelets over the last 24 hours, there has been no improvement in the platelet count. What is the most appropriate next step in management of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Post-transfusion purpura presents with severe thrombocytopenia and hemorrhage 5–10 days after transfusion, especially in multiparous women. IVIG is the first-line treatment, as platelet transfusions are typically ineffective due to ongoing alloimmune destruction.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme/diagnostic marker pairs is incorrectly matched with its associated disease?
questions.correct_answer: A. Beta Glucocerebrosidase – Von Gierke’s disease
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Beta Glucocerebrosidase – Von Gierke’s disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Beta-glucocerebrosidase deficiency is seen in Gaucher’s disease, not Von Gierke’s. Von Gierke’s is caused by a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase. Recognizing enzyme-disease pairings is key in metabolic and diagnostic pathology.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with pruritic lesions on his thigh that have progressively enlarged over several weeks. On examination, the lesions are circular with a clear center and an erythematous, raised border. The lesions are as shown in the image. How would you best describe these lesions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Annular

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Annular lesions are ring-shaped with active, erythematous borders and central clearing. They are most commonly associated with dermatophyte infections such as tinea corporis. This presentation differs from nummular/discoid lesions, which are uniform without central clearing, and target lesions, which have three distinct concentric zones.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding genital tuberculosis are correct? Genital tuberculosis typically begins in the fallopian tubes and later spreads to other pelvic organs. Hysterosalpingography in genital TB shows findings such as cornual block and tobacco-pouch appearance. The most common causative agent is Mycobacterium leprae. A doughy abdomen on palpation and menstrual irregularities are common clinical features. A recurrent pelvic inflammatory mass in an unmarried woman is likely to be tubercular in origin.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Statements 1, 2, 4, and 5 are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Genital tuberculosis is a common cause of infertility and chronic pelvic inflammatory disease in developing countries. It classically involves the fallopian tubes and presents with menstrual irregularities, a doughy abdomen, and specific radiological findings like cornual block and tobacco-pouch hydrosalpinx .
  • ➤ Genital tuberculosis
  • ➤ cornual block
  • ➤ tobacco-pouch hydrosalpinx

questions.text: A child is brought to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of progressive loss of central vision. Fundus examination is largely normal, and systemic examination is unremarkable. An electro-oculogram (EOG) shows an Arden Index <1.50. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Best’s Vitelliform Dystrophy

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Best’s Vitelliform Dystrophy is a juvenile-onset macular dystrophy characterized by central vision loss and an abnormal electro-oculogram with an Arden index <1.50. It is an important differential for macular disorders in children.
  • ➤ Best’s Vitelliform Dystrophy

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents for a routine health check-up. He is asymptomatic and his vitals are within normal limits. His lab reports show a haemoglobin level of 13 g/dL. What is the estimated oxygen-carrying capacity of his blood?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 17 mL/dL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The oxygen-carrying capacity of blood can be calculated by multiplying haemoglobin concentration (g/dL) by 1.34 mL/g, the approximate amount of oxygen that each gram of haemoglobin can bind. This calculation is crucial for understanding oxygen delivery in clinical settings.

questions.text: In the context of defense mechanisms, which of the following is an example of sublimation?

options.label: A
options.text: A student who is angry with his teacher starts breaking furniture

options.label: B
options.text: A person who feels anxious starts excessive hand-washing

options.label: C
options.text: A man with aggressive impulses becomes a professional boxer

options.label: D
options.text: A woman who dislikes her mother constantly forgets to call her

questions.correct_answer: C. A man with aggressive impulses becomes a professional boxer
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A man with aggressive impulses becomes a professional boxer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sublimation is the transformation of a socially unacceptable impulse into socially acceptable behaviour. It is a mature defence mechanism. E.g. Vincent van Gogh transformed his emotional turmoil into expressive paintings, using art as a form of sublimation to cope with his struggles.
  • ➤ Sublimation is the transformation of a socially unacceptable impulse into socially acceptable behaviour.
  • ➤ It is a mature defence mechanism. E.g. Vincent van Gogh transformed his emotional turmoil into expressive paintings, using art as a form of sublimation to cope with his struggles.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male reports a gradual decline in memory and increasing difficulty with coordination over the past 6 months. His partner has also noticed personality changes and episodes of involuntary limb movements. His medical history is unremarkable, but his father and grandfather developed similar progressive neurologic symptoms at ages 50 and 55, respectively. Genetic testing is planned. Which of the following best describes the underlying genetic mechanism responsible for his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Epigenetic silencing due to methylation error

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Expanded trinucleotide tandem repeat

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Huntington disease is caused by an expanded CAG trinucleotide repeat in the HTT gene. It presents with progressive cognitive decline, personality changes, chorea, and shows genetic anticipation due to further expansion of repeats in successive generations.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man from Pune with a known history of alcohol-related cirrhosis presents to the emergency department with increasing confusion, low-grade fever, and abdominal discomfort over the last 2 days. On examination, he is drowsy, oriented only to place, has flapping tremors, and a tense, distended abdomen. There is no history of hematemesis or GI bleeding. Laboratory tests reveal serum bilirubin 6.4 mg/dL and creatinine 1.2 mg/dL. Diagnostic paracentesis is performed, and the fluid appears clear. Ascitic fluid analysis has been performed and the report is shown below: What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cefotaxime and IV albumin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cirrhotic patients with ascitic neutrophil count ≥250/mm³, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis should be promptly treated with third-generation cephalosporins and IV albumin to prevent renal dysfunction and reduce mortality, especially when bilirubin and creatinine are elevated.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a complaint of persistent pain in his right tibia for the past 3 weeks. He reports mild swelling but denies fever or chills. The pain is localized and worsens with activity. Physical examination reveals tenderness and mild swelling over the anterior aspect of the tibia. There is no significant medical history, and his vital signs are normal. X-ray is given below, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Brodie’s abscess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image shows Brodie’s abscess, which is a long-standing localized pyogenic abscess in the bone, seen in subacute or chronic pyogenic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the clinic with symptoms of irritability, depression, and peripheral neuropathy. She reports fatigue, headaches, and difficulty concentrating. Her medical history includes poor dietary habits and frequent alcohol consumption. On physical examination, she has glossitis (inflamed tongue) and cheilosis (cracks at the corners of her mouth). Blood tests reveal microcytic anemia with a low hemoglobin level. Given the neurological symptoms, her physician orders a urine test to assess the excretion of metabolites. The results show elevated levels of xanthurenic acid in the urine. Further assessment indicates a deficiency of a specific vitamin involved in amino acid metabolism. The physician explains that this deficiency disrupts tryptophan metabolism, resulting in the accumulation of xanthurenic acid. questions.text: A 21-year-old man from Delhi is admitted to the ICU after sustaining severe traumatic brain injury following a road traffic accident. questions.text: A 60-year-old man with no family history of colorectal cancer undergoes a screening colonoscopy due to his age. The test, which has a sensitivity of 95% and a specificity of 90%, shows a positive result. Given the general population prevalence of colorectal cancer at his age is approximately 1.5%, how should the positive result be interpreted?

options.label: A
options.text: Highly likely to have colorectal cancer given the test’s high sensitivity.

options.label: B
options.text: Confirm with additional diagnostic tests due to the potential for false positives.

options.label: C
options.text: Begin immediate cancer treatment based on the positive result.

options.label: D
options.text: Dismiss the positive result due to low cancer prevalence.

questions.correct_answer: B. Confirm with additional diagnostic tests due to the potential for false positives.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Confirm with additional diagnostic tests due to the potential for false positives

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Even when a screening test for a condition like colorectal cancer shows high sensitivity and specificity, the prevalence of the disease significantly affects the interpretation of a positive result. Given the low prevalence, positive results should be confirmed with additional testing to ensure accuracy and prevent unnecessary treatment. This cautious approach helps in making informed and safe treatment decisions for patients.

Expert opinions expressed in a treatise: Expert opinions printed in books are accepted as evidence without oral evidence of the author. Deposition of a medical witness taken in lower court: Accepted as evidence in a higher court when it has been recorded and attested by a magistrate in presence of the accused who had an opportunity to cross-examine the witness. Report of certain government scientific experts: Admitted as evidence without their oral examination, e.g. reports of Chemical Examiner or Director of Fingerprint Bureau/Haffkeine Institute/CFSL. Evidence given by a witness in a previous judicial proceeding: Admitted in a subsequent judicial proceeding when the witness is dead or cannot be found or is incapable of giving evidence or cannot be called without unreasonable delay or expense to the court. Public records: Birth and death certificates, and certificates of marriage. Hospital records: Routine entries, such as date of admission, discharge, pulse, temperature, etc. are admissible without oral evidence.
  • ➤ Dying declaration: Accepted in court as legal evidence in event of victim’s death.
  • ➤ Expert opinions expressed in a treatise: Expert opinions printed in books are accepted as evidence without oral evidence of the author.
  • ➤ Deposition of a medical witness taken in lower court: Accepted as evidence in a higher court when it has been recorded and attested by a magistrate in presence of the accused who had an opportunity to cross-examine the witness.
  • ➤ Report of certain government scientific experts: Admitted as evidence without their oral examination, e.g. reports of Chemical Examiner or Director of Fingerprint Bureau/Haffkeine Institute/CFSL.
  • ➤ Evidence given by a witness in a previous judicial proceeding: Admitted in a subsequent judicial proceeding when the witness is dead or cannot be found or is incapable of giving evidence or cannot be called without unreasonable delay or expense to the court.
  • ➤ Public records: Birth and death certificates, and certificates of marriage.
  • ➤ Hospital records: Routine entries, such as date of admission, discharge, pulse, temperature, etc. are admissible without oral evidence.

questions.text: A 65-year-old hospitalized man presents with profuse watery diarrhea that began 5 days after completing a course of clindamycin for pneumonia. He is afebrile, but appears mildly dehydrated. On physical exam, there is mild lower abdominal tenderness without peritonitis. The clinician suspects Clostridium difficile–associated diarrhea (CDAD) and sends a stool sample for evaluation. Which of the following is considered the best initial diagnostic approach for the detection of Clostridium difficile in this patient's stool?
questions.correct_answer: B. Glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assay
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assay

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman at 11 weeks gestation presents to the outpatient obstetrics clinic with complaints of heavy vaginal bleeding and crampy lower abdominal pain for the past 2 days. questions.text: A 23-year-old sexually active female presents with a concern regarding her transdermal contraceptive patch. options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Apply a new patch and use a condom for 1 week

options.text: Apply a new patch without additional contraceptive protection

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Apply a new patch and use a condom for 1 week

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ If a transdermal contraceptive patch has been off or partially detached for more than 24 hours, a new patch should be applied immediately, and a backup method (such as condoms) should be used for 7 days to maintain contraceptive effectiveness.

questions.text: A norovirus outbreak has occurred on a cruise ship, affecting multiple passengers. questions.text: A 53-year-old man with end-stage renal disease undergoes a deceased donor kidney transplant. questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents with a lifelong history of easy bruising and mucosal bleeding. He reports frequent nosebleeds and prolonged bleeding after minor cuts. questions.text: A pathology laboratory technician in a tertiary hospital collects nasopharyngeal swabs for a patient undergoing radioiodine therapy for thyroid cancer. questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Nd:YAG laser posterior capsulotomy is/are true? questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of gallstones undergoes an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy. questions.text: A 28-year-old woman undergoing metabolic evaluation for a suspected lipid metabolism disorder is found to have impaired fatty acid synthesis.   • ➤ The other structures—portal vein, SMA, and SMV—are located posterior to the pancreas and are within the surgical field during this dissection, increasing their risk of injury.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the clinic for evaluation of recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and eruptive skin lesions. Physical examination reveals multiple small yellowish papules over the extensor surfaces of the arms and buttocks. Laboratory testing shows markedly elevated triglyceride levels. Genetic testing reveals a defect in the apolipoprotein required to activate lipoprotein lipase (LPL), resulting in impaired clearance of chylomicrons. Which of the following apolipoproteins is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Apo CII

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Apolipoprotein CII is required to activate lipoprotein lipase, enabling the hydrolysis of triglycerides from chylomicrons and VLDL into free fatty acids for tissue uptake.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks gestation undergoes a routine obstetric ultrasound. Which of the following best describes this abnormal placental finding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Velamentous cord insertion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Velamentous cord insertion is a placental abnormality where fetal vessels traverse the membranes before inserting into the placenta, increasing the risk of vessel rupture , vasa previa , and fetal hemorrhage . It is diagnosed by prenatal ultrasound and requires careful monitoring.
  • ➤ Velamentous cord insertion
  • ➤ vessel rupture
  • ➤ vasa previa
  • ➤ fetal hemorrhage

questions.text: Which of the following staining techniques is most appropriate to confirm the presence of Nocardia species?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Modified acid-fast stain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nocardia species are weakly acid-fast, and their presence is best confirmed using a modified acid-fast stain, such as the Kinyoun technique.

questions.text: A 28-year-old nulliparous woman desires long-term contraception and is interested in any additional health benefits the method may provide. Which of the following non-contraceptive benefits is associated with CuT 380A use?​
questions.correct_answer: D. Reduced risk of endometrial cancer.​
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Reduced risk of endometrial cancer.​

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CuT 380A use is associated with a reduced risk of endometrial cancer, likely due to the local inflammatory response it induces in the endometrium.

questions.text: Which of the following is true with respect to examination of a female victim of sexual assault?

options.label: A
options.text: Toluidine dye should be used to detect recent microinjuries on genitalia before taking the swab for sperm detection

options.label: B
options.text: History should not be taken from the victim if her age < 12 years

options.label: C
options.text: Radiological confirmation of age of victim should be done in every case of rape victim examination

options.label: D
options.text: Per speculum examination may not be needed in young victim if there is no history of penetration

questions.correct_answer: D. Per speculum examination may not be needed in young victim if there is no history of penetration
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Per speculum examination may not be needed in young victim if there is no history of penetration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Per speculum examination may not be needed in a young female victim of sexual assault if there is no history of penetration. Invasive procedures must be guided by the history and clinical findings, especially in children.
  • ➤ Per speculum examination may not be needed in a young female victim of sexual assault if there is no history of penetration.

questions.text: A 37-year-old obese woman reports worsening heartburn after meals for the past 5 years. She undergoes upper endoscopy and biopsy of the distal esophagus, shown in the histology image below. Based on these findings, which of the following statements regarding this condition are true? The biopsy reveals a transformation of normal squamous epithelium into columnar epithelium with intestinal features. Goblet cell hyperplasia is the hallmark of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma. This metaplastic process is typically a response to chronic acid reflux and can predispose to adenocarcinoma. The lamina propria shows atrophy as a result of repeated mucosal injury.
questions.correct_answer: A. Only statements 1 and 3 are correct
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Only statements 1 and 3 are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Barrett esophagus is characterized by columnar metaplasia with goblet cells in the distal esophagus, secondary to chronic GERD. This metaplasia increases the risk of developing esophageal adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman reports widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and unrefreshing sleep for the past several months. Physical examination reveals tenderness in multiple soft tissue areas without joint swelling or redness. Laboratory tests, including inflammatory markers, are within normal limits. She is diagnosed with fibromyalgia and started on a medication that works by inhibiting the reuptake of both serotonin and norepinephrine. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Milnacipran

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Milnacipran is an SNRI that treats fibromyalgia by inhibiting the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine, helping to modulate pain and fatigue in patients with this condition.
  • ➤ Milnacipran is an SNRI that treats fibromyalgia by inhibiting the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine, helping to modulate pain and fatigue in patients with this condition.
  • ➤ Note - 3 main SNRI – Venlafaxine, Duloxetine and Milnacipran
  • ➤ Note - 3 main SNRI – Venlafaxine, Duloxetine and Milnacipran

questions.text: A rural elementary school has reported a sharp decline in cognitive performance among children, along with fatigue, irritability, and attention difficulties over the past year. A public health team investigates possible environmental exposures and finds that the school’s drinking water has a pH of 6.2, total dissolved solids (TDS) of 480 mg/L, and fluoride levels of 1.8 ppm. Other parameters, including turbidity and bacterial counts, are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these students’ symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Fluoride toxicity from prolonged water consumption

options.label: B
options.text: Lead leaching from corroded pipes due to acidic water

options.label: C
options.text: Chronic arsenic poisoning from groundwater contamination

options.label: D
options.text: Methemoglobinemia due to excessive nitrate levels in well water

questions.correct_answer: B. Lead leaching from corroded pipes due to acidic water
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lead leaching from corroded pipes due to acidic water

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Water with low pH (<6.5) increases the risk of lead leaching from old pipes, contributing to chronic neurotoxicity and cognitive impairment in children.
  • ➤ Water Quality Guidelines:
  • ➤ Water Quality Guidelines:

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with acute left flank pain radiating to the groin. The pain is colicky in nature and associated with mild nausea. On examination, there is tenderness over the left costovertebral angle (CVA). His urine dipstick shows microscopic hematuria. After controlling his colic, the following imaging is done. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Plain CT KUB

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with suspected renal colic , non-contrast CT KUB is the gold standard for diagnosing urinary stones. It identifies stone size, location, and degree of obstruction , guiding further management. X-ray KUB alone is inadequate , as it may miss radiolucent stones. ESWL, URS, or conservative management should only be considered after confirming stone characteristics on imaging.
  • ➤ In patients with suspected renal colic , non-contrast CT KUB is the gold standard for diagnosing urinary stones.
  • ➤ suspected renal colic
  • ➤ non-contrast CT KUB
  • ➤ gold standard
  • ➤ It identifies stone size, location, and degree of obstruction , guiding further management. X-ray KUB alone is inadequate , as it may miss radiolucent stones.
  • ➤ identifies stone size, location, and degree of obstruction
  • ➤ X-ray KUB alone is inadequate
  • ➤ ESWL, URS, or conservative management should only be considered after confirming stone characteristics on imaging.
  • ➤ ESWL, URS, or conservative management should only be considered after confirming stone characteristics on imaging.

There is no active bleeding, but a deep laceration is noted over the volar aspect of the proximal phalanx. What structure is most likely injured?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Flexor digitorum profundus tendon
